comments:
On a seemingly random basis, Eclipse creates a partial workspace on my C: drive,
even though my workspace is on O:.

My workspace is set to O:\Users\RBaldwin\Eclipse\workspace where drive O: is
mapped to \\Sourceprose\dfs\Dev.

Directories and files created outside workspace:
C:\dfs
  Dev
    Users
      Rbaldwin
        Eclipse
          workspace
            .metadata [.lock, version.ini]
              .plugins
                org.eclipse.core.resources
                  .history   [.index]
                  .root      [.properties, 2.tree]
                  .safetable [org.eclipse.core.resources]
                org.eclipse.debug.core
                org.eclipse.debug.ui
                org.eclipse.jdt.core      [prefs.ini]
                org.eclipse.jdt.launching [prefs.ini, libraryInfos.xml]
                org.eclipse.jdt.ui        [prefs.ini]
                org.eclipse.pde.core      [prefs.ini]
                org.eclipse.ui            [dialog_settings.xml]
                org.eclipse.ui.ide        [prefs.ini, dialog_settings.xml]
                org.eclipse.ui.workbench  [dialog_settings.xml, workbench.xml]

Which build are you using? (Help -> About)
Is there any information in your .log file? (/workspace/.metadata/.log)
Is that directory structure mimiced on drive O:?

I'm using 3.0 M8 (build id: 200403261517).  I've included the .log file, but I
don't think it will help because all of the files on my C: drive have times
between 20:00 and 20:10 on 2004-03-30 and the log entries start on 2004-03-31.

What I've indicated is on my C: drive is only a partial workspace; there are
many more directories and files in my real workspace.  For example, in my real
workspace, the org.eclipse.core.resources directory has a .projects directory
that contains a directory for each of my projects.  Also, the .root directory
has a 3.tree file instead of a 2.tree file.

BTW, this has been happening randomly for months, since before the switch to the
OSGi runtime.

This could be a UNC path thing.  If you sub the UNC path for the drive letter 
and (magically) strip off the first segment you get the path for the external 
workspace data.  I don't think that this is due to anything in the runtime.  

Ron, do you ever see this when you spec -data?  What about now that the 
workspace chooser is available (if you don't spec -data)?

Curious that it happens only sometimes.

This has definitely happened while using -data (since it has been happening for
a while, long before the workspace chooser).  I don't remember if I was using
-data or the workspace chooser the last time it happened, but since I'm using
the workspace chooser now, I'll let you know if/when it happens again.

Jeff, please confirm that this issue has been fixed by your work regarding
windows network path (can't remember the acronym) and close if appropriate.

Ron, please verify with the RC0 candidates that this has been fixed.
Marking as RC1 in case it has not been fixed.

want to confirm this one.  It was fixed and I worked with UNC paths for several 
days with no problems.  yesterday however I tried something that I think should 
have worked but it did not.  Will investigate.

The problems I was seeing were due to a bug in the VM I was using.  It was 
experimental and has problems creating FileOutputStreams on UNC paths.  
Everything is behaving as expected on standard production VMs.

Closing.
